title: Elon Musk
added: * [[List of awards and honors received by Elon Musk]]

title: Elon Musk
deleted: [[Virgin Hyperloop One|Hyperloop One]], a company unaffiliated with Musk, announced in July 2017 that it had its first successful test run on its DevLoop track in Nevada, which had lasted 5.3 seconds and reached a top speed of 70 mph.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/14/15960686/hyperloop-one-test-success-interview-giegel-pishevar|title=Talking to Hyperloop One about its big 'Kitty Hawk' moment – and what comes next|last=Hawkins|first=Andrew J.|date=July 14, 2017 |website=The Verge|access-date=July 14, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200520012511/https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/14/15960686/hyperloop-one-test-success-interview-giegel-pishevar|archive-date=May 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In 2021 [[Khan Academy]] accepted a $5 million donation from the Musk Foundation. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=id_MB2RClG4 |title=Elon Musk $5 million donation to Khan Academy thank you |access-date=January 14, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbctv18.com/buzz/elon-musk-donates-5-million-to-khan-academy-7988651.htm |title=Elon Musk donates $5 million to Khan Academy |access-date=January 14, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: * {{cite book|last1=Kidder|first1=David|last2=Hoffman|first2=Reid|title=The Startup Playbook: Secrets of the Fastest Growing Start-Ups from the founding Entrepreneurs|publisher=Chronicle Books|year=2013|location=San Francisco|isbn=9781452105048|ref=Kidder}}

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In 2014, Musk announced that Tesla would allow its technology patents to be used by anyone in good faith in a bid to entice automobile manufacturers to speed up the development of electric cars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/all-our-patent-are-belong-you |title=All Our Patent Are Belong To You |publisher=Tesla Motors |access-date=November 4, 2015 |archive-date=July 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704234722/https://www.teslamotors.com/blog/all-our-patent-are-belong-you |url-status=live }}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: Musk's relationship with [[Amber Heard]], who he had reportedly been "pursuing" since 2012,<ref name"hollywood"/> was publicly revealed in April 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jensen|first=Erin|date=April 24, 2017|title=Amber Heard, Elon Musk make 'Cheeky' public debut together|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2017/04/24/amber-heard-elon-musk-dating-public-debut-instagram-posts/100834568/|work=USA Today|access-date=January 28, title: Elon Musk
deleted: In July 2014, Musk was asked by [[cartoonist]] [[Matthew Inman]] and William Terbo, the grandnephew of [[Nikola Tesla]], to donate $8 million toward the construction of the [[Tesla Science Center at Wardenclyffe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theoatmeal.com/comics/tesla_model_s2 |title=What it's like to own a Tesla Model S – Part 2 |publisher=theoatmeal.com – The Oatmeal |access-date=December 13, 2020 |archive-date=September 1, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901055950/http://theoatmeal.com/comics/tesla_model_s2 |url-status=live }}</ref> Ultimately, Musk agreed to donate $1 million toward the project and additionally pledged to build a Tesla Supercharger in the museum car park.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/10/elon-musk-donates-1-million-to-the-oatmeals-nikola-tesla-museum/ |title=Elon Musk Donates Million to the Oatmeal's Nikola Tesla Museum |last=Kumparak |first=Greg |website=TechCrunch |publisher=AOL |access-date=November 4, 2015 |archive-date=December 26, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171226022502/https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/10/elon-musk-donates-1-million-to-the-oatmeals-nikola-tesla-museum/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In January 2015, Musk donated $10 million to the [[Future of Life Institute]] to run a global research program aimed at keeping AI beneficial to humanity.<ref>{{Citation |year=2015 |title=Elon Musk donates M to keep AI beneficial |publisher=[[Future of Life Institute]] |url=http://futureoflife.org/2015/10/12/elon-musk-donates-10m-to-keep-ai-beneficial |access-date=January 20, 2015 |archive-date=February 28, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228042613/https://futureoflife.org/2015/10/12/elon-musk-donates-10m-to-keep-ai-beneficial/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="mashable_tallinn">{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2015/01/13/elon-musk-stephen-hawking-artificial-intelligence |title=Elon Musk Donates M To Make Sure AI Doesn't Go The Way of Skynet |publisher=Mashable |year=2015 |access-date=June 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200822214830/https://mashable.com/2015/01/13/elon-musk-stephen-hawking-artificial-intelligence/|archive-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref>

In October 2018, in an effort to help solve the [[Flint water crisis]], Musk and the Musk Foundation donated over $480,000 to install new water fountains with filtration systems for access to clean water at all [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]], Michigan schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/08/us/elon-musk-flint-schools-water-filtration-trnd/index.html |title=Flint schools are getting safe water fountains thanks to Elon Musk |first=Christina |last=Zdanowicz |work=CNN |date=October 8, 2018 |access-date=October 14, 2018 |archive-date=October 15, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181015170351/https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/08/us/elon-musk-flint-schools-water-filtration-trnd/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref> {{As of|2019}}, approximately 30,000 children in all 12 area schools have free, safe drinking water from the water filtration systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/minda-zetlin/elon-musk-flint-michigan-schools-water-children-water-fountains-stations-lead-contamination.html|title=Elon Musk Is Now Providing Water Filtration to Flint Michigan Schools|date=October 12, 2019|access-date=January 1, 2020|archive-date=January 2, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200102034359/https://www.inc.com/minda-zetlin/elon-musk-flint-michigan-schools-water-children-water-fountains-stations-lead-contamination.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Musk has been a top donor for the [[ACLU]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/46184-aclu-respond-to-elon-musk-donor-claims|title=ACLU Thanks Elon Musk for Being a 'Top Donor'|first=Oscar|last=Gonzalez|website=Inverse|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=November 9, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109031149/https://www.inverse.com/article/46184-aclu-respond-to-elon-musk-donor-claims|url-status=live}}</ref> In October 2019, Musk donated $1 million to '[[Team Trees|#TeamTrees]]' a tree planting initiative to plant 20 million trees led by the [[YouTube]] community and in collaboration with [[Arbor Day Foundation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-30/musk-donates-1-million-trees-to-global-reforestation-campaign|title=Musk Donates 1 Million Trees to Global Reforestation Campaign|publisher=Bloomberg|access-date=November 18, 2019|date=October 31, 2019|last=Cheok|first=Melissa|archive-date=October 31, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191031040141/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-30/musk-donates-1-million-trees-to-global-reforestation-campaign|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Strub|first=Chris|date=October 29, 2019|title=Elon Musk Donates $1 Million To #TeamTrees, Changes Twitter Identity To 'Treelon'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrisstrub/2019/10/29/teamtrees/?sh=67c660a15f6e|work=Forbes|access-date=January 11, 2021}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: Musk is chairman of the Musk Foundation, which states its purpose is to provide solar-power energy systems in disaster areas as well as other goals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.muskfoundation.org/|title=Musk Foundation|website=muskfoundation.org|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=November 21, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121012101/http://muskfoundation.org/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":12" /> Since 2002, the foundation has made over 350 contributions. Around half were to scientific research or education nonprofits. Notable beneficiaries include the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], his alma mater the University of Pennsylvania, and his brother Kimball's Big Green.<ref name="charity"/> Musk is a trustee of the [[X Prize Foundation]],<ref>{{cite news|last=High|first=Peter|date=May 16, 2019|title=Meet The Winners Of Elon Musk's $15 Million XPRIZE To End Global Illiteracy|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterhigh/2019/05/16/meet-the-winners-of-elon-musks-15-million-xprize-to-end-global-illiteracy/#5a1bb97139e7|access-date=September 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201107232433/https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterhigh/2019/05/16/meet-the-winners-of-elon-musks-15-million-xprize-to-end-global-illiteracy/#5a1bb97139e7|archive-date=November 7, 2020|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Feloni|first=Richard|date=March 21, 2018|title=Silicon Valley could help the last people you'd expect — and Elon Musk has given $15 million to a contest that will prove it|work=Business Insider|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-peter-diamandis-xprize-eliminate-illiteracy-2018-3|access-date=September 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190519175629/https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-peter-diamandis-xprize-eliminate-illiteracy-2018-3|archive-date=May 19, 2019}}</ref> and, in 2012, signed [[The Giving Pledge]], promising to give at least half of his fortune to charity.<ref name="forbes_2012">{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Luisa|date=April 19, 2012|title=The Giving Pledge Signs on 12 More Wealthy Americans Including Tesla's Elon Musk And Home Depot's Arthur Blank|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/luisakroll/2012/04/19/the-giving-pledge-signs-on-12-more-wealthy-americans-including-teslas-elon-musk-and-home-depots-arthur-blank|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201021003041/https://www.forbes.com/sites/luisakroll/2012/04/19/the-giving-pledge-signs-on-12-more-wealthy-americans-including-teslas-elon-musk-and-home-depots-arthur-blank/|archive-date=October 21, 2020|access-date=December 13, 2020|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="charity">{{cite news|last=Cuccinello|first=Hayley C.|date=September 8, 2020|title=Elon Musk Has Promised To Give At Least Half His Fortune To Charity. Here's How Much He's Donated So Far|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hayleycuccinello/2020/09/08/elon-musk-has-promised-to-give-at-least-half-his-fortune-to-charity-heres-how-much-hes-donated-so-far/?sh=606951e73c8c|work=Forbes|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=December 13, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201213235544/https://www.forbes.com/sites/hayleycuccinello/2020/09/08/elon-musk-has-promised-to-give-at-least-half-his-fortune-to-charity-heres-how-much-hes-donated-so-far/?sh=606951e73c8c|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: ====Ownership of Tesla====

{{as of|2016|January|29|df=US}}, Musk owned about 28.9 million Tesla shares, which equated to about 22% of the company.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/elon-musk-buys-tesla-shares-cheap-pays-hefty-tax-bill-with-own-cash-2016-01-29 |title=Elon Musk exercises Tesla options, pays million tax bill with own cash |first1=Claudia |last1=Assis |first2=Jeremy C. |last2=Owens |website=MarketWatch |access-date=February 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200621165753/https://www.marketwatch.com/story/elon-musk-buys-tesla-shares-cheap-pays-hefty-tax-bill-with-own-cash-2016-01-29|archive-date=June 21, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/29/10873576/elon-musk-100-million-option-exercise-stock-tesla |title=Elon Musk bought $100 million more worth of Tesla this week |last=Ziegler |first=Chris |date=January 29, 2016 |publisher=Vox Media |website=The Verge |access-date=February 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200803130505/https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/29/10873576/elon-musk-100-million-option-exercise-stock-tesla|archive-date=August 3, 2020}}</ref> In January 2018, Musk was granted an option to buy up to 20.3 million shares if Tesla's market value were to rise to $650 billion. Majority shareholder approval for this package was approved in March 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/mar/21/elon-musk-tesla-bonus-pay|title=Elon Musk wins approval for 'staggering' pay deal with potential $55bn bonus|date=March 21, 2018|access-date=September 24, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200822005044/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/mar/21/elon-musk-tesla-bonus-pay|archive-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> The grant was also meant to end speculation about Musk's potential departure from Tesla to devote more time to his other business ventures.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-23/tesla-tops-ups-all-in-bet-on-musk-with-2-6-billion-option-award|title=Musk's New Pay Deal Could Make Him the World's Richest Man – If Tesla Succeeds|date=January 23, 2018|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=March 6, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200825132846/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-23/tesla-tops-ups-all-in-bet-on-musk-with-2-6-billion-option-award|archive-date=August 25, 2020}}</ref> A report by advisory firm Glass Lewis & Co. to its clients argued against granting the options.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/434579a8-2311-11e8-ae48-60d3531b7d11|title=Elon Musk's $2.6bn stock options package at Tesla opposed by ISS|last=Waters|first=Richard|date=March 8, 2018|work=Financial Times|access-date=December 11, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191211121000/https://www.ft.com/content/434579a8-2311-11e8-ae48-60d3531b7d11|archive-date=December 11, 2019}}</ref> {{As of|2019|12|31|df=US}}, Musk owns 38,658,670 shares or 20.8% of all Tesla shares.<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 28, 2020|title=Tesla 2020 Proxy Statement|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000156459020027321/tsla-def14a_20200707.htm#OWNERSHIP_SECURITIES|access-date=September 19, 2020|website=sec.gov|archive-date=September 24, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200924171425/https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000156459020027321/tsla-def14a_20200707.htm#OWNERSHIP_SECURITIES|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In summar 2020, Neuralink "was hoping to start human trials in 2021, although this was pending approval from the US medical regulator."<ref name=dtmusk/>

On February 1, 2021, Musk demonstrated a [[chimpanzee]] able to "play video games" with a Neuralink technology implant. Said Musk: "You can't see where the implant is and he's a happy monkey. We have the nicest monkey facilities in the world. We want them to play mind-Pong with each other."<ref name="dtmusk">{{cite news |last1=Boland |first1=Hannah |title=Elon Musk says he wired a monkey's brain to play video games |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2021/02/01/elon-musk-reveals-wired-monkeys-brain-play-video-games/ |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=February 1, 2021}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: On May 8, 2020, Musk posted a series of tweets in which he promised to sell his "physical possessions" and subsequently signed letters of intent to sell several of his California residences.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hotten|first=Russell|date=May 5, 2020|title=Elon Musk homes reportedly for sale after vow to sell possessions|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52530316|work=BBC|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211021404/https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52530316|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gittelsohn|first1=John|last2=Waller|first2=Hailey|date=July 1, 2020|title=Elon Musk Selling California Properties Listed for $62.5 Million|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-01/elon-musk-selling-california-properties-to-los-angeles-developer|work=Bloomberg|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=October 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201001184534/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-01/elon-musk-selling-california-properties-to-los-angeles-developer|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In July 2016, Tesla began developing [[Tesla Autopilot|Autopilot]], their advanced driver-assistance system, in-house after [[Mobileye]] ended its partnership with Tesla, citing safety concerns following a fatal crash in which the driver of a Model S using Autopilot was killed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.recode.net/2016/7/26/12285930/tesla-mobileye-self-driving-cars|title=In the wake of a fatal crash, Tesla will quit using Mobileye's chips for Autopilot vision|date=July 26, 2016|publisher=ReCode|last1=Bhuiyan|first1=Johana|access-date=July 26, 2016|archive-date=July 27, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160727135722/http://www.recode.net/2016/7/26/12285930/tesla-mobileye-self-driving-cars|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Kieler|first=Ashlee|title=Tesla Supplier Says It Broke With Carmaker Over Autopilot Safety Concerns|url=https://www.consumerreports.org/consumerist/tesla-supplier-says-it-broke-with-carmaker-over-autopilot-safety-concerns/|access-date=August 17, 2020|website=Consumer Reports|archive-date=February 22, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200222005332/https://www.consumerreports.org/consumerist/tesla-supplier-says-it-broke-with-carmaker-over-autopilot-safety-concerns/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Ramsey|first=Mike|date=July 26, 2016|title=Mobileye Ends Partnership With Tesla|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mobileye-ends-partnership-with-tesla-1469544028|access-date=August 17, 2020|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=August 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200808120546/https://www.wsj.com/articles/mobileye-ends-partnership-with-tesla-1469544028|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: Tesla, Inc. (originally Tesla Motors) was incorporated in July 2003 by [[Martin Eberhard]] and [[Marc Tarpenning]], who financed the company until the [[Series A round]] of funding.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla |title=A Brief History of Tesla |date=October 8, 2014 |access-date=June 11, 2015 |website=TechCrunch |publisher=TechCrunch.com |last=Burns |first=Matt |archive-date=March 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180306225331/https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Both men played active roles in the company's early development prior to Musk's involvement.<ref name="From Archive.org-7620615">{{cite web |url=http://www.marketbusinessnews.com/tesla-motors/12064 |title=Tesla Motors Inc. – Company Information |publisher=Market Business News |date=February 12, 2014 |access-date=April 16, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212093533/http://www.marketbusinessnews.com/tesla-motors/12064 |archive-date=February 12, 2014 |url-status=dead |first=Joseph |last=Nordqvist}}</ref> Musk led the Series A round of investment in 2004, joining Tesla's board of directors as its chairman.<ref name="MasterPlan">{{cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |title=The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan (just between you and me) No. 124 |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=August 2, 2006 |access-date=October 3, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802142703/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me|archive-date=August 2, 2010 |url-status=live}} {{Self-published source|inline|date=May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How Much Equity Did Elon Musk Get From Investing In Tesla's Series A?|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2014/12/29/how-much-equity-did-elon-musk-get-from-investing-in-teslas-series-a/#11415dd62a9f|date=December 29, 2014|access-date=December 23, 2019|archive-date=January 29, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129035019/https://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2014/12/29/how-much-equity-did-elon-musk-get-from-investing-in-teslas-series-a/#11415dd62a9f|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunchBriefHistory">{{Cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla/ |title=A Brief History of Tesla |date=October 8, 2014 |access-date=July 17, 2015 |work=TechCrunch|last=Burns |first=Matt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717064829/https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla/#/slide2 |archive-date=July 17, 2015 |quote="Tesla was founded not by Elon Musk, but rather by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning in July 2003. The two bootstrapped the fledgling auto company until Elon Musk led the company's US$7.5 million Series A financing round in February 2004."}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Tesla has named two new board members – here's the full list of company directors |work=Business Insider |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-board-of-directors-full-list-elon-musk-chairman-replacement-2018-8 |last=Rapier |first=Graham |date=December 28, 2018 |access-date=December 23, 2019 |archive-date=December 23, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191223220729/https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-board-of-directors-full-list-elon-musk-chairman-replacement-2018-8 |url-status=live }}</ref> Musk took an active role within the company and oversaw Roadster product design but was not deeply involved in day-to-day business operations.<ref>[[Elon Musk#Vance|Vance (2015)]], p. 159.</ref> Following a series of escalating conflicts in 2007 and the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2008 financial crisis]], Eberhard was ousted from the firm.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Quirky: The remarkable story of the traits, foibles, and genius of breakthrough innovators who changed the world|last=Schilling|first=Melissa|publisher=PublicAffairs|year=2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Morrison |date=October 15, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/external/venturebeat/2008/10/15/15venturebeat-elon-musk-steps-in-as-ceo-at-tesla-lays-off-99182.html |title=Musk steps in as CEO |work=The New York Times |access-date=December 13, 2020 |archive-date=February 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204120521/http://www.nytimes.com/external/venturebeat/2008/10/15/15venturebeat-elon-musk-steps-in-as-ceo-at-tesla-lays-off-99182.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Musk assumed leadership of the company as CEO and product architect in 2008, positions he still holds today. A 2009 lawsuit settlement with Eberhard designated Musk as a Tesla co-founder, along with Tarpenning and two others.<ref name=CNET/><ref name=FastCompany/> {{as of|2019}}, Musk is the longest tenured CEO of any automotive manufacturer globally.<ref name="auto6">{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/industry-shift-four-departures-longest-190424759.html|title=Industry Shift: With Four Departures This Year, Who Is The Longest-Tenured Automotive CEO?|website=Yahoo|date=July 8, 2019|access-date=December 13, 2020|archive-date=December 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229014127/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/industry-shift-four-departures-longest-190424759.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: * ''[[Elon Musk: Tesla, SpaceX, and the Quest for a Fantastic Future]]'' (2015 biography)

title: Elon Musk
deleted: *{{cite web |url=https://www.asme.org/career-education/early-career-engineers/me-today/engineer-in-focus-elon-musk |title=Engineer in Focus: Elon Musk |first= Paul |last= Glanville |publisher=asme.org|access-date=May 5, 2020 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181119011009/https://www.asme.org/career-education/early-career-engineers/me-today/engineer-in-focus-elon-musk |archive-date=November 19, 2018}}}} <!-- Please do not remove the following two sentences without discussion on the Talk page --> He is the founder, [[chief executive officer|CEO]], [[Chief technology officer|CTO]], and chief designer of [[SpaceX]]; early investor,{{efn|A lawsuit settlement agreed to by Eberhard and Tesla in September 2009 designated five people as company founders, including Musk, Eberhard, JB Straubel, Mark Tarpenning, and Ian Wright.<ref name=CNET>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/tesla-motors-founders-now-there-are-five/ |title=Tesla Motors founders: Now there are five|last=LaMonica|first=Martin |website=CNET|date=September 2009|access-date=April 17, 2020|quote=Tesla Motors and co-founder Martin Eberhard announced an agreement over who can claim to be a founder of the company on Monday.}}</ref><ref name=FastCompany>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/1367866/tesla-lawsuit-drama-ends-five-company-founders-emerge|title=Tesla Lawsuit Drama Ends as Five Company Founders Emerge|last=Schwartz|first=Ariel|date=September 21, 2009|website=Fast Company|access-date=April 14, 2020|quote=Eberhard and Musk have reached a rather unexpected resolution–instead of agreeing to share the title of "founder", the pair has designated five people as company founders, including Musk, Eberhard, JB Straubel, Mark Tarpenning, and Ian Wright.}}</ref>}} CEO, and product architect of [[Tesla, Inc.]]; founder of [[The Boring Company]]; co-founder of [[Neuralink]]; and co-founder and initial co-chairman of [[OpenAI]]. A [[centibillionaire]], Musk is currently one of the richest people in the world.<ref name="net"/>

title: Elon Musk
added: Musk also has received acclaim for his work on making [[space exploration]] more affordable. [[Dmitry Rogozin]], the head of the [[Roscosmos|Russian space agency]], praised the Musk's contributions in the field, and stated that he treats the Musk' work with respect.<ref>https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5683ba3c9a7947320104ea9b</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: Musk also has received acclaim for his work on making [[space exploration]] more affordable. [[Dmitry Rogozin]], the head of the [[Roscosmos|Russian space agency]], praised the Musk's contributions in the field, and stated that he treats the Musk' work with respect.<ref>https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5683ba3c9a7947320104ea9b</ref><ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-30/elon-musk-stepping-on-toes-in-space-race-russia-official-says</ref>

title: Elon Musk
added: Musk also has received acclaim for his work on making [[space exploration]] more affordable. [[Dmitry Rogozin]], the head of the [[Roscosmos|Russian space agency]], praised the Musk's contributions in the field, and stated that he treats the Musk' work with respect.<ref>https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5683ba3c9a7947320104ea9b</ref><ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-30/elon-musk-stepping-on-toes-in-space-race-russia-official-says</ref> In part for his contributions to space travel, Musk was elected a fellow of [[the Royal Society]].<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/samshead/2018/07/16/elon-musk-signed-a-350-year-old-book-with-deepminds-demis-hassabis/?sh=3c464a7f6764</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: Musk is recognized for his efforts to combat [[global warming]]. According to [[Bill Gates]], "what Elon did with Tesla is one of the greatest contributions to climate change anyone's ever made".<ref>https://www.ndtv.com/offbeat/underestimating-elon-musk-is-not-a-good-idea-says-bill-gates-2373044</ref> [[Al Gore]] called himself "a big fan of Tesla and of Elon Musk".<ref>https://finance.yahoo.com/news/al-gore-rejects-call-assume-elon-musks-role-tesla-chairman-184936627.html</ref> For his [[renewable energy]] work and advocacy, Musk has received several environmentalist awards, including the [[National Wildlife Federation]]'s Connie Award<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20090626035342/http://www.nwf.org/about/connieawards2008.cfm</ref> and a [[Global Green]] award.<ref>https://electrek.co/2017/04/11/tesla-independent-board-members/</ref>

Musk has also received acclaim for his work on making [[space exploration]] more affordable. [[Dmitry Rogozin]], the head of the [[Roscosmos|Russian space agency]], praised Musk's contributions in the field and stated that he "treats [Musk's] work with respect".<ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-30/elon-musk-stepping-on-toes-in-space-race-russia-official-says</ref> In part for his contributions to space travel, Musk was elected a fellow of the [[Royal Society]] in 2018.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/samshead/2018/07/16/elon-musk-signed-a-350-year-old-book-with-deepminds-demis-hassabis/?sh=3c464a7f6764</ref>

He was listed among the [[Time 100|''Time'' 100 Most Influential People in the World]] in 2010, 2013 and 2018, and was ranked joint-first on the ''[[Forbes]]'' list of the "Most Innovative Leaders of 2019".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/innovative-leaders/#55480e0526aa|title=America's Most Innovative Leaders|date=August 28, 2019|accessdate=February 18, 2021}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: ===Medical research===

Musk is one of the authors of a [[scientific paper]] published in the journal [[Nature Communications]]. The paper describes findings on the immunity to [[COVID-19]].<ref>https://www.theverge.com/2021/2/22/22295821/spacex-employees-covid-study-paper-antibody-research-elon-musk</ref><ref>https://www.wsj.com/articles/elon-musk-got-4-000-spacex-workers-to-join-a-covid-19-study-heres-what-he-learned-11613826001</ref>

title: Elon Musk

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In 2021, findings of an [[Antibody testing|antibody-testing]] program that Musk and a SpaceX medical executive worked with doctors and academic researchers to create were published in [[Nature Communications]] with Musk listed as a co-author.<ref>{{cite news|last=Krouse|first=Sarah|date=February 20, 2021|title=Elon Musk Got 4,000 SpaceX Workers to Join a Covid-19 Study. Here's What He Learned.|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/elon-musk-got-4-000-spacex-workers-to-join-a-covid-19-study-heres-what-he-learned-11613826001|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=February 23, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title= Discrete SARS-CoV-2 antibody titers track with functional humoral stability |url= https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-21336-8 |journal= [[Nature Communications]] | doi = 10.1038/s41467-021-21336-8 |first1= Yannic C. |last1= Bartsch |first2= Stephanie |last2= Fischinger |first3=  Sameed M. |last3= Siddiqui  |first4= Zhilin |last4= Chen |first5= Jingyou |last5= Yu |first6= Makda |last6= Gebre |first7= Caroline |last7= Atyeo |first8= Matthew J. |last8= Gorman |first9= Alex Lee |last9= Zhu |first10= Jaewon |last10= Kang |first11= John S. |last11= Burke |first12= Matthew |last12= Slein |first13= Matthew J. |last13= Gluck |first14= Samuel |last14= Beger |first15= Yiyuan |last15= Hu |first16=Justin |last16= Rhee |first17= Eric |last17= Petersen |first18= Benjamin |last18= Mormann |first19= Michael |last19= de St Aubin |first20= Mohammad A. |last20= Hasdianda |first21= Guruprasad |last21= Jambaulikar |first22=Edward W. |last22= Boyer |first23=Pardis C. |last23= Sabeti |author-link23= Pardis Sabeti |first24= Dan H. |last24= Barouch |author-link24= Dan Barouch |first25= Boris D. |last25= Julg |first26= Elon R. |last26= Musk |first27= Anil S. |last27= Menon |first28= Douglas A. |last28= Lauffenburger |author-link28= Doug Lauffenburger |first29= Eric J. |last29= Nilles |first30= Galit |last30= Alter |author-link30= Galit Alter |date=2021-02-15 | access-date=2021-02-20}}</ref>
